A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Arise from
  • Perivascular epithelioid cells

Types
  • Sporadic AMLs: Present in the 4th-6th decades, typically small, solitary, and slow-growing.
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Present earlier (3rd-4th decades), larger, multiple, bilateral, and tend to grow.

Symptoms

  • Abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, anemia.
  • Impaired kidney function, usually due to hemorrhage (severe complication).
  • Wunderlich syndrome: Nontraumatic kidney hemorrhage.

Risk Factors for AML Complications
  • Pregnancy: Increased risk of hemorrhage
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Higher risk of CKD and ESKD
  • Epithelioid AMLs: Potential for malignant transformation, metastasis, and local recurrence.

 

Risk factors for hemorrhage:

  • AML size (>6 cm)
  • Increased vascularity
  • Large intralesional aneurysms (>5 mm)
  • Exophytic growth pattern.

Histology

Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

Diagnosis
  • CT: (Investigation of choice) Presence of intralesional fat and neovascular mass.
  • USG: Appears as hyperechoic
  • Immunocytochemical analysis: Differentiates AML from RCC, using markers like HMB-45 and melan-A.

Treatment
  • Observation (tumors <4 cm)
  • Nephron-Sparing Surgery(Partial nephrectomy) (larger tumors or those with a high risk of bleeding)
  • Angioembolization (acute hemorrhage).
  • Medications (mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and sirolimus).

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Description

Definition

It is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress.

Clinical Features
  • Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow.
  • Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood.
  • Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling.
  • Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers.
  • Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase.
  • Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase.

Types
  • Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease):
    • Occurs without underlying disease.
    • More common and has a better prognosis.
  • Secondary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Syndrome):
    • Occurs due to an underlying condition (e.g., scleroderma, lupus).
    • Often more severe.

Management
  • Lifestyle Modifications: Avoid cold exposure, stress reduction, and smoking cessation.
  • Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), alpha-blockers (e.g., prazosin), and other vasodilators.
  • Avoidance of Triggers: Avoid cold, beta-blockers, and caffeine.
  • Advanced Treatments: Surgical sympathectomy for severe cases.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Presentation and History: Based on symptoms and triggers.
  • Nailfold Capillaroscopy: To examine capillary changes.
  • Blood Tests: To identify underlying autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.

questions.text: A chronic-alcoholic presents to the emergency room with acute pain in the abdomen in the epigastric region radiating to the back with nausea, anorexia, and occasional vomiting. Investigations showed elevated amylase levels (3 times) and total count. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
X-ray Features
  • Sentinel loop sign:
    • Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.
    • Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign
  • Colon cut-off sign:
    • Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.
    • Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for the chronic alcoholic patient’s presentation with confusion, aphasia, unstable gait, and symptoms related to Wernicke’s encephalopathy?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Vit B1

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

  • Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

  • Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation.

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles

options.label: C
options.text: USG is the gold standard investigation for this condition

questions.correct_answer: B. Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
questions.explanation:
Clinical Presentation
  • Typical onset: 3 to 6 weeks of age
  • Symptoms:
    • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting (Option A ruled out)
    • Visible gastric peristalsis
    • Palpable "olive-like" mass in the abdomen (hypertrophied pylorus), best felt from the left side
      • Test feed: Gastric peristalsis is seen passing from left to right across the abdomen, and in a relaxed (feeding) baby, the pyloric ‘tumor’ is palpable as an ‘olive’ in the right upper quadrant.
    • Dyselectrolytemias-
      • Hypochloremia
      • Hypokalemia due to persistent vomiting
      • Metabolic alkalosis. (Option D ruled out)

Ultrasound (Gold Standard)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Characteristic "doughnut sign" indicating thickened pyloric muscle
  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • Pyloric muscle thickness ≥ 4 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • "Cervix sign" on long-axis view
    • "Target sign" on short-axis view

Barium Meal (Less Common)

Can assist in diagnosis but is less accurate than ultrasound, it reveals:

  • "String sign": Thin streak of contrast through narrowed pylorus
  • "Railroad track sign": Two thin lines of contrast indicating mild narrowing
  • "Double track sign": Similar to railroad track sign, indicating thickened muscle

questions.text: A 28-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute mastitis?
Which lymph node is most commonly involved in prostate cancer?
questions.explanation:
• Most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years.
  • Most common among Afro-American

Risk factor

  • Advanced age
  • High-fat diet

Protective factors

(Mnemonic: LESA)

  • Lycopene
  • Vitamin E
  • Selenium
  • Vitamin A

Pathology

  • Most common site- peripheral zone (75%) > transitional zone (15%) > central zone (10%)
  • Most common histological type is adenocarcinoma
  • Most common genetic alteration seen in CA prostate- hypermethylation of GSTP1 (Glutathione transferase promoter region 1) located on chromosome 11.
  • 70-80% of the cases.
  • Microscopy: small, crowded, absent basal layer, lack of branching

Clinical features
  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Bladder outlet obstruction.
  • Haematuria
  • Pelvic pain, back pain, arthritic pain in sacroiliac joint-features of secondaries
  • On per rectal examination: hard, nodular, irregular often with loss of median groove.

Routes of spread
  • Most common route of spread- haematogenous (skeletal metastases: pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae)
  • Lymphatic: Internal iliac, external iliac lymph nodes, retroperitoneal lymph nodes, mediastinal nodes and occasionally the supraclavicular nodes.

Investigations

  • DRE (Digital Rectal Exam): Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage
  • PSA (prostate-specific antigen) Test: Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer
  • TRUS (Transrectal Ultrasound): Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities
  • mpMRI (Multiparametric MRI): Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread
  • Prostate Biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells

Management

  • Active Surveillance: For low-risk cases; regular monitoring
  • Radical Prostatectomy: Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative
  • Radiation Therapy: High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy
  • Hormone Therapy: Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases
  • Chemotherapy: Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

options.label: A
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

questions.correct_answer: A. Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism
questions.explanation:
Fournier's Gangrene

Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Causative Organisms

Mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria in a fulminating inflammation of the subcutaneous tissues. (Option A)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Diabetes mellitus (Option B ruled out)
  • Malnutrition
  • Alcoholism
  • Immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management

Initial Treatment:

  • Fluid resuscitation.
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.

Additional Measures:

  • Daily rounds (high rates mortality and morbidity) (Option C ruled out)
  • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
  • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
  • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
  • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after sustaining an RTA and injury to the lower chest. On presentation, the patient is stable, and vitals are normal. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?

A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Transurethral resection of the tumor
questions.explanation:
Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

questions.text: A 44-year-old lady presents to the hospital with a ballotable flank mass. The mass measures 4 cm on CT imaging. Urine examination shows malignant cells. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Management

RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy: Involves removing only the tumor while preserving the remainder of the kidney. (Option A)

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. (Option C ruled out)

Indications: Larger tumors or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation: Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumors(T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: A soldier arrives at a referral hospital 24 hours after experiencing a shrapnel injury to his right thigh caused by a high-speed projectile. He expresses significant discomfort at the site of the wound. Upon examination, there is evidence of crepitus. Which of the following microorganisms is the probable culprit behind his current state?
questions.explanation:
A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens (Option D)

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues).

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the qSOFA score components?
Inhalational induction of choice in children is:
questions.explanation:
Sevoflurane

Properties

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated ether with low blood solubility (λb/g 0.65), allowing for rapid induction and emergence.

Its non-pungency makes it suitable for inhalation induction, especially in pediatric patients. It is used with conventional vaporizers.

Uses

Ideal for smooth and rapid inhalation induction, particularly in daycare procedures (4-8% concentration with nitrous oxide and oxygen).

It is commonly used for both pediatric and adult anesthesia.

C/I

Should be avoided in cases of severe hypovolemia, susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Systemic Effects

Cardiovascular

Mild myocardial depression with slight reduction in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. It causes minimal heart rate increase and may prolong the QT interval.

Hepatic

Decreases portal vein flow but increases hepatic artery flow, maintaining overall hepatic perfusion.

Renal

Slightly decreases renal blood flow but has no known association with significant renal toxicity.

Compound A, a degradation product of sevoflurane, is nephrotoxic in animals but has no known adverse effects on humans.

Neuromuscular

Provides adequate muscle relaxation for intubation but is often combined with other agents or muscle relaxants.

Cerebral

Slight increases in cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure. High concentrations may impair CBF autoregulation. Seizures have not been reported.

Respiratory

Depresses respiration and helps reverse bronchospasm. Thus agent of choice in asthmatics.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect induced by cisplatin chemotherapy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - GI

questions.text: Which of the following is most suitable for intravenous regional anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Indications
  • Suitable for minor surgical procedures on the upper or lower extremities (hand surgeries, forearm procedures, and foot surgeries).
  • Used when general anesthesia is not necessary and for patients with contraindications to other forms of anesthesia.

Anesthetic Agents
  • Commonly used local anesthetics include
    • Lidocaine (most frequent)
    • Prilocaine

Procedure Steps
  • Tourniquet Application: Apply a tourniquet to the proximal part of the extremity to prevent blood flow and keep the local anesthetic localized.
  • Venous Access: Establish intravenous access in the selected limb.
  • Administration of Anesthetic agent: Inject the local anesthetic into the IV line, typically in a volume of 40-50 mL.

Tourniquet Management

  • The tourniquet should be inflated to a pressure that is approximately 50 mmHg above systolic blood pressure.
  • It is typically safe to keep the tourniquet inflated for 30-60 minutes; prolonged inflation can increase the risk of complications.

Advantages
  • Provides effective analgesia with minimal systemic absorption.
  • Allows for a bloodless surgical field.
  • Quick onset of action and ease of administration.

Disadvantages and Complications
  • Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) Can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation.
  • Tourniquet Pain
  • Nerve Damage

Contraindications
  • Infection at the injection site or over the tourniquet.
  • Severe peripheral vascular disease.
  • Patient refusal or inability to cooperate.

 

Lipid Emulsion Therapy
  • Used as a treatment for Local anesthesia systemic toxicity, acts by sequestering the local anesthetic from circulation and mitigating toxic effects.
  • Administer a 20% lipid emulsion intravenously if toxicity occurs.

questions.text: What is the initial management approach for urinary symptoms in a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.explanation:
Management

Medical Management
  • 1st line management: ⍺ 1 Blocker
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Silodosin
    • Most commonly used: Tamsulosin (⍺ 1A selective Blocker) (Option B)
  • 2nd line: 5 𝛼 Reductase inhibitors
    • Finasteride (Option C ruled out)
    • Dutasteride
    • Triptorelin pamoate
  • Combination treatment with ⍺ 1 Blocker and 5 𝛼 Reductase inhibitors are used in large prostate.

Surgical Management
  • Indications:
    • No improvement in medical management.
    • Acute retention of urine
    • Chronic urinary retention with residual urine of more than 200 ml.
    • Complications like hydroureter, hydronephrosis, stone formation, recurrent infection, and gross haematuria
  • Surgeries:
    • Gold standard- TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate). (Option A ruled out)
    • Trans urethral incision of prostate (TUIP)
    • Open prostatectomy procedures

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)

Etiopathogenesis

  • Role of hormones in BPH:
    • DHT (Dihydrotestosterone)
      • DHT, derived from testosterone via 5-alpha reductase, binds to androgen receptors in the prostate, promoting cellular proliferation and contributing to prostatic enlargement.
    • Estrogen
      • Estrogen levels increase relative to testosterone in aging men, influencing prostate growth through activation of estrogen receptors, particularly ER-α, in the prostatic tissue.
  • Affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees.
  • Most common site of origin: submucosal glands of periurethral transitional zone
  • Secondary changes in the bladder (due to increased force of contraction of detrusor muscles):
    • Collagen deposition
    • Detrusor muscle hyperplasia
    • Detrusor muscle hypertrophy.

Clinical features
  • Age affected: Men over 50 years
  • Common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men more than 70 years of age: BPH
  • Obstructive symptoms:
    • Poor flow/stream
    • Hesitancy
    • Intermittency
    • Incomplete voiding-High post-void residual urine
    • Dribbling of urine
  • Irritative symptoms:
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia

Investigations

  • Urine microscopy and C/S.
  • Ultrasound abdomen- residual urine and prostate size.
  • Uroflowmetry (Qmax):
    • Normal: > 15 ml/sec.
    • Equivocal: 10-15 ml.
    • Low: <10 ml
  • Cystometry:
    • Voiding pressure
    • Normal: <60 cm of H₂O
    • Equivocal: 60- 80 cm of H₂O
    • High: >80 cm of H₂O
  • Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)

Complications

  • Retention
  • Haematuria
  • Urinary infection
  • Stone formation

questions.text: Which of the following are true about nephroblastoma except:

options.label: A
options.text: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.correct_answer: D. Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children
questions.explanation:
Cause

Caused by mutations in WT1 and WT2 genes on chromosome 11.

Associated syndromes

  • Denys-Drash Syndrome (DDS): A rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the WT1 gene, characterized by a triad of Wilms' tumor, nephrotic syndrome due to diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and male pseudohermaphroditism
  • WAGR Syndrome: A rare genetic condition caused by a deletion on chromosome 11p13, leading to a combination of Wilms' tumor, aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary abnormalities, and intellectual disability.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS): A genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, increased tumor risk, macroglossia, abdominal wall defects, and hemihyperplasia, often due to abnormalities on chromosome 11p15.5.
  • Perlman Syndrome: A rare genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, developmental delay, intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and an increased risk of Wilms' tumor, often caused by mutations in the DIS3L2 gene.

Clinical Presentation
  • Most common malignant pediatric renal tumor.

Triad:

  • Asymptomatic abdominal mass (MC presentation)
  • Fever (disappears after tumor resection)
  • Hematuria (Gross/Microscopic)

Rarely: Pain

Investigations

USG- Primary investigation

CECT- Investigation of choice.

MRI - For better soft tissue visualization.

Treatment

Chemotherapy followed by surgery. (Option A ruled out)

Multimodal approach

  • Surgery: Radical nephrectomy or nephron-sparing surgery
  • Chemotherapy: VCD regimen

Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Dactinomycin/Doxorubicin

  • Radiation therapy: For higher stages or unfavorable histology

Staging

I. Disease confined to the kidney and completely resectable

II. Tumor extends beyond the kidney but can be excised completely

Ill. Residual disease after resection with positive lymph nodes and massive spillage

IV. Blood-borne metastasis

V. Bilateral disease

Prognosis

Most important Prognostic Factor - Histology > Stage

Metastasis

Mainly through a hematogenous route into: (Option C ruled out)

  • Lungs (MC) (Option B ruled out)
  • Liver
  • Bones (Rarely)

questions.text: A female patient complains of swelling and pain in her great toe. Her uric acid level is found to be high. A drug that reduces uric acid levels is prescribed. Which of the following enzymes should the drug inhibit?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Xanthine

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine (spindle poison)

  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids

  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: A homosexual man presents with painful defecation and a protruding mass from the anal canal. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What is the appropriate course of action for managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Anal Canal Carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection: Strongly linked to anal canal cancer, particularly high-risk subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)
  • Anal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (AIN): A precancerous condition significantly increases the risk of progression to anal canal cancer, especially from AIN II or III.
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV-positive, transplant recipients)
  • Sexual Practices: Anal intercourse increases HPV transmission risk.
  • History of Other Genital Neoplasia: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
  • Extensive Anogenital Condylomata: The presence of extensive anal warts linked to HPV infection

Clinical features
  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Palpable Mass
  • Pruritus (Itching)
  • Discharge
  • Incontinence
  • Fistulation (anterior tumour extension in women can create a fistula between the anus and vagina).
  • Appearance:
    • Anal margin tumours: Often resemble malignant ulcers with raised, hardened edges.
    • Anal canal tumours: Typically palpable as irregular, hardened, and tender ulcerated areas.
  • Lymph Node Involvement: Enlarged lymph nodes in the perirectal or groin regions may indicate cancer spread.

Investigations

  • Biopsy from the Anal Region: The primary diagnostic test to confirm the presence of carcinoma.
  • FNAC of Inguinal Nod (assess metastasis).
  • USG Abdomen (check for any spread of the disease).
  • MRI of the Perineum (assess the extent of the tumour).
  • Proctosigmoidoscopy: Assess the upper extent of the tumour within the anal canal.

Management

  • Chemoradiation (Nigro regimen): The preferred treatment modality for carcinoma of the anal canal. (Option C)
    • Chemotherapy Drugs: Commonly used drugs include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), bleomycin, vincristine, and adriamycin.
    • Radiotherapy: Often used alone in advanced cases where the tumour is not resectable.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) with Colostomy: For persistent or recurrent disease after combined modality therapy (CMT), or for cases where the tumor does not respond to chemoradiation. (Option B ruled out)
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Involves using 5-FU, cisplatin, and mitomycin C before surgery to shrink the tumour.

questions.text: A psychiatrist prescribes lithium for a patient who is diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding lithium?

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose

Lithium

Mechanism of action

  • Increase the level of amine (if the mood is low) by inhibiting the Glycogen synthase kinase-3 enzyme
  • Decrease the level of amine (if the mood is high)
    • Inhibits inositol monophosphatase enzyme
    • Inhibits the release of amines
    • Stabilises neuronal membrane

Uses

  • Bipolar disorder
  • Hypnic headache (occurs in sleep)
  • Anti-suicidal action (another drug is clozapine)
  • Resistant cases of depression

Adverse effects
  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect (Option A) when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Granisteron + dexamethasone + aprepitant

Drugs

Mechanism of Action

Granisetron or Ondansetron

They are 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, which blocks receptors in the gut and brain stimulated by serotonin released during chemotherapy, reducing nausea and preventing vomiting.

Dexamethasone

A corticosteroid with anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, it reduces gastrointestinal inflammation and suppresses the release of chemicals in the brain that trigger nausea and vomiting.

Aprepitant

It is a substance P/neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor antagonist that works by blocking NK1 receptors, inhibiting the action of substance P (a neurotransmitter involved in triggering nausea and vomiting).

This medication is often used in combination with others as it targets different pathways in the development of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), offering a more comprehensive approach to prevention and management. This combination therapy is particularly effective in preventing both acute and delayed CINV.

Antiemetic agents

Class & Drugs

Uses

Side effects

5-HT3 receptor antagonists

  • Ondansetron
  • Palonosetron
  • Granisetron
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting
    • Early onset: Ondansetron
    • Late onset: Palonosetron
  • Headache
  • QT prolongation
    • Maximum: Dolasetron
    • Minimum: Palonosetron
  • Hypotension

Centrally acting D2 antagonists

  • Metoclopramide
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
  • Gastroparesis.
  • Paralytic ileus.
  • Bowel cleansing.
  • Extra-pyramidal symptoms (acute dystonia).
  • Severe hyperprolactinemia.
  • Domperidone
  • Mild-moderate vomiting.
  • GERD.
  • Minor EPS features.
  • Mild hyperprolactinema.

Neurokinin-1 inhibitors

  • Aprepitant
  • Fosaprepitant
  • Rolapitant
  • Netupitant
  • Late-onset nausea and vomiting (DOC)
  • Rolapitant:
    • Neutropenia.
    • Hiccups.
    • Decreased appetite.
    • Dizziness.

Cannabinoids

  • Dronabinol.
  • Nabilone.
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
  • Appetite stimulant (can be used in HIV and anorexia patients.
  • Hypotension.
  • Conjunctival injection (bloodshot eyes)

Antihistamines

  • Cyclizine
  • Meclizine.
  • Promethazine.
  • Diphenhydramine.
  • Motion sickness
  • Sedation.
  • Doxylamine
  • Morning sickness (given with pyridoxine)
  • Dry mouth
  • Drowsiness
  • Dry mouth
  • Constipation

Muscarinic receptor antagonists

  • Hyoscine (scopolamine)
  • Motion sickness (drug of choice, available as a transdermal patch)
  • Dry mouth.
  • Visual disturbances.
  • Drowsiness.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy for perforation peritonitis. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound.

Occurrence

Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

Types

 
  1. Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat.
  2. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera).

Risk Factors

General:

  • Malnourishment
  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Renal failure
  • Jaundice
  • Sepsis
  • Cancer
  • Treatment with steroids
  • Emergency surgery

Local:

  • Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension
  • Poor local wound healing
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure

Clinical Presentation
  • Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid), (Option A)
  • Possible evisceration,
  • Popping sensation during straining or coughing.

Treatment

  • Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised.
  • Complete dehiscence with evisceration:
    • Requires urgent reoperation.
    • Tension suturing is done.
    • Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury.
    • Antibiotic therapy; fluid management.

questions.text: Cholera is known to cause diarrhea through its interaction with specific receptors in the human body. Which of the following is known to make it easier for cholera toxin to enter the body through the intestinal mucosa?

What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who experienced nausea and vomiting after being involved in a road traffic accident, and was brought to the emergency room unconscious, based on the findings of the NCCT brain?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Epidural Hematoma (EDH)

(Option A)

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

(Option B ruled out)

Mechanism
  • Rupture of an artery, often the middle meningeal artery, usually due to a skull fracture, commonly in the temporal bone.

Two contexts:

  • High-energy injury: Rupture of cortical surface vessels.
  • Low-energy injury: Venous bleeding, common in older adults on anticoagulants.

Clinical Presentation
  • Classic: Transient loss of consciousness, lucid interval, rapid neurological decline.
  • Headaches are common.
  • Brain compression signs: Contralateral hemiparesis, reduced consciousness, ipsilateral pupillary dilation.
  • Variable presentation depending on injury severity and timing.
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure: Headache, reduced consciousness, focal neurological deficits.

CT Appearance

Lentiform (lens-shaped or biconvex) hyperdense lesion between the skull and the brain.

 

Diffuse concave hyperdense (acute), isodense (subacute), or hypodense (chronic) crescent-shaped lesions over the brain surface, often crossing suture lines.

 

Management

Neurosurgical emergency; requires immediate evacuation, usually by craniotomy.

Depends on size, location, and clinical status:

1. Large or worsening hematomas: Urgent evacuation by craniotomy or craniectomy.

2. Smaller, stable bleeds: Conservative management initially, with surgery if needed.

Summary

EDH often follows a predictable course with a lucid interval.

SDH has a more variable presentation and distinct CT appearance.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to feeding difficulties, vomiting, and failure to thrive. The child's history reveals that the infant was born full-term and had a normal birth weight. On physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced, and the liver is palpable below the costal margin. Oil drop Cataracts are also noted on eye examination. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of galactose in the blood and urine. Based on these clinical findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. (Option A)
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis

Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,

Severe mental retardation

Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)

Oil drop Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens

Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic tobacco chewer presents with a whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
It is a progressive condition involving deep fibrosis in the oral mucosa, characterized by fibrous bands and considered a precancerous lesion.

Cause
  • Hypersensitivity to tobacco, betel nut, chilli, areca nut, vitamin deficiencies, localised collagen disorders.
  • Leads to alteration of collagen metabolism causing juxtaepithelial progressive inflammatory fibrosis of the submucosa.
  • This leads to atrophy and dysplasia.

Clinical features

  • Common in Asians
  • Males and females are equally affected.
  • Soreness in the mouth more during meals
  • Burning, also more while eating
  • Vesicular eruptions
  • Trismus
  • Difficulty in protruding tongue
  • Fibrosis and scarring
  • Ankylosing glossitis

 

Management

  • Cessation of causative factors(tobacco, chilli, areca nut)
  • Oral hygiene
  • Dexamethasone local injections
  • Hydrocortisone
  • HCG submucosal injection
  • Vitamin and iron supplementation
  • Surgical excision with graft
  • Stem cell therapy

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness, which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Myasthenia gravis:

Pathophysiology

Autoimmune disease is caused by antibodies targeting acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Disruption in neuromuscular transmission occurs through:

  • Blockage of acetylcholine receptors.
  • Complement-mediated inflammation leads to:
    • Reduced receptor count.
    • Damage to the end plate.

Clinical features
  • Fatigable muscle weakness: Muscle strength decreases with continued use, especially:
    • Later in the day
    • After exercise
  • No sensory or CNS involvement, distinguishing it from other neurological disorders.

Common Initial Symptoms:

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Weakness can spread to:
    • Chewing, swallowing, and speaking muscles
    • Limb muscles

Diagnosis

Tensilon (edrophonium) Test

  • This involves the injection of Edrophonium (a short-acting anticholinesterase agent) into individuals with a deficiency of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Steps: 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30–60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.
  • If muscle strength improves after the administration of edrophonium, it indicates the presence of Myasthenia Gravis.

Management

Anticholinesterase agents (inhibit the breakdown of ACh by acetylcholinesterase and increase presynaptic levels of ACh, allowing for muscle contraction).

  • Pyridostigmine (drug of choice)
  • Neostigmine
  • Ambenonium

questions.explanation:
Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. (Option A)
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

  • Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis
  • Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,
  • Severe mental retardation
  • Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)
  • Oil drop Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens, reversible cataract
  • Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

questions.text: Oxaloacetate is produced from which of the following amino acid?

A 40-year-old smoker presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea. His BP is 190/110 mmHg, and heart rate is 105 bpm. What is the initial management?
questions.explanation:
It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

Clinical features
  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

Investigations

  • Stable Patient: CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • Unstable Patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm): TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) (preferred investigation of choice)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

Management

Initial Management: Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes:

  • Blood pressure control (which is usually high at presentation) (Option A)
  • Strict pain management,
  • Prompt referral for specialist management

Surgical Management

Type A (or type I and II) dissections

Type B (or type III) dissections

Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention.

  • Synthetic graft if needed
  • Anastomosis

 

Endovascular stenting of type A dissections.

Initial management:

  • Antihypertensive drugs
  • Monitoring on an acute care unit

 

Complicated cases: If pain worsens, fails to resolve, or malperfusion signs appear (e.g., organ, limb, or neurological symptoms)

  • Percutaneous endovascular stents
  • Surgery (rarely used)

DeBakey Classification

(Based on the pattern of dissection)

Type I

Both ascending and descending aorta are involved

Type II

Only the ascending aorta is involved

Type III

Only the descending aorta is involved

Stanford Classification

(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection)

Type A

 

Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved.

(It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification)

Type B

 

Only the descending aorta is involved.

(It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation:
Horseshoe Kidney

It is a congenital condition in which the two kidneys are fused at the lower ends, forming a U-shaped structure.

Cause

  • During fetal development the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure.
  • This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen.

Clinical Features
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Hematuria
  • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

Investigation

  • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualization of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.

CT Abdomen showing Horseshoe kidney

  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
    • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."
    • High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

 

 

Management

  • Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment, but should be monitored periodically.
  • Symptomatic Patients:
    • UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty
    • Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal
    • UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent.
    • Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue.
    • Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labor) due to the kidney's abnormal position.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals is best known for insulin secretion stabilisation?
questions.explanation:
Dietary Sources

Grains, beans, nuts, cheese, meat, shellfish.

Therapeutic Use

Zinc reduces copper absorption in Wilson’s disease.

Zinc-Dependent Enzymes
  • Carboxypeptidase
  • Carbonic anhydrase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ethanol dehydrogenase
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase
  • RNA polymerase (required for protein biosynthesis)

Functions
  • Antioxidant RoleExtracellular superoxide dismutase is zinc-dependent, contributing to zinc’s antioxidant properties.
  • Insulin and ZincZinc stabilizes insulin in beta cells of the pancreas but is not present in released insulin.
  • Taste Sensation Gusten, a zinc-containing protein in saliva, is important for taste sensation.

Deficiency Manifestations
  • Poor wound healing
  • Skin lesions, hyperkeratosis, dermatitis, alopecia
  • Impaired spermatogenesis
  • Reduced T and B lymphocyte numbers, impaired macrophage function
  • Psychiatric disorders: depression, dementia, and cognitive decline (e.g., Alzheimer's)

Acrodermatitis Enteropathica
  • Acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.)
  • Diarrhea, alopecia, ophthalmoplegia, hypogonadism

Toxicity Manifestations
  • Chronic Toxicity: Gastric ulcers, pancreatitis, anemia, nausea, vomiting, pulmonary fibrosis
  • Acute Toxicity: Fever, excessive salivation, headache, anemia

questions.text: Please determine the instrument provided.
Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate, as shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Norepinephrine

Description

Norepinephrine, or noradrenaline, is a sympathomimetic drug used primarily as a vasopressor.

Mechanism of Action (MOA)

It acts on α1 and β1 adrenergic receptors and has some affinity for alpha-2 receptors.

  • Activation of α1 receptors causes vasoconstriction, increasing peripheral resistance and blood pressure.
  • Activation of β1 receptors increases heart rate and myocardial contractility.

Uses
  • Treatment of acute hypotension (e.g., septic shock, cardiogenic shock).
  • Cardiac arrest.

Side effects
  • Cardiovascular: Arrhythmias, bradycardia, hypertension.
  • CNS: Anxiety, headache, tremor.
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting.
  • Respiratory: Respiratory difficulty, dyspnea.
  • Metabolic: Hyperglycemia, lactic acidosis.

Contraindications
  • Peripheral vascular thrombosis (risk of ischemia).
  • During anesthesia with cyclopropane or halothane (due to the risk of arrhythmias).
  • Hypotension is due to blood volume deficits (hypovolemia) until an adequate fluid replacement.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Fistula-in-Ano

A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Investigation

  • MRI: Maps the fistula tunnel and provides detailed images of the sphincter muscle and pelvic floor structures. (Investigation of choice) (Option D)
  • Endoscopic Ultrasound: It uses high-frequency sound waves to identify the fistula, sphincter muscles, and surrounding tissues.
  • Fistulography: An X-ray procedure using injected contrast to visualize the anal fistula tunnel. (1st investigation) (Option A ruled out)
  • Examination Under Anesthesia: Allows for thorough evaluation of the fistula tunnel and identification of potential complications.
  • Fistula Probe: A specialized instrument is inserted through the fistula to identify the fistula tunnel.
  • Anoscopy: A small endoscope is used to visualize the anal canal for assessment of fistulas during anoscopy.

Management:

Fistulotomy

  • Opening the fistula tract to heal by secondary intention.
  • Used for intersphincteric and trans-sphincteric fistula involving <30% of external sphincter; not for anterior fistula in women.

Fistulectomy

  • Removal of the fistula using diathermy cautery for better visualization of anatomy.
  • Effective for understanding the fistula's anatomy and extensions.

Setons

  • Materials are inserted into the fistula tract for drainage or gradual cutting.
  • Loose setons promote drainage; tight/cutting setons cut through muscle over time.

Advancement Flaps

  • Closing the internal opening with a flap of anorectal mucosa is used when the sphincter complex is not extensively indurated.
  • Effective for certain fistula configurations.

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Probenecid

Uricosuric drugs

Mechanism

Inhibit OAPT transporter/ URAT-1 in kidney ⇒ Inhibits reabsorption ⇒ Increase excretion of uric acid

Drugs

1. Probenecid:

  • Side effects: diarrhoea, hypersensitivity, uric acid stones
  • Contraindication: nephrolithiasis, renal failure
  • Precaution: take plenty of oral fluids
  • Concomitant colchicine or NSAIDs indicated in attack of gout

2. Sulphinpyrazole:

  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug
  • Recommended in both acute and chronic gout

3. Benzbromarone:

  • Safe in renal failure
  • Contraindication – Liver diseases

4. Lesinurad

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine (spindle poison) (Option A)

 
  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors

  • Allopurinol (DOC) (Option D)
  • Oxipurinol
  • Febuxostat (Option B)

MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme

  • Pegloticase
  • Rasburicase

MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents

  • Probenecid (OptionC)
  • Benzbromaron
  • Sulfinpyrazone
  • Lesinurad

MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to a psychiatrist with symptoms of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and difficulty sleeping for 2 months. The psychiatrist makes the diagnosis of a major depressive disorder. Which drug is best for the disorder, as mentioned earlier?

Major classes of medications used in treating depression

Class

Examples

Use

SSRIs

Fluoxetine, Sertraline, Escitalopram, Citalopram, Paroxetine

First-line due to safety and tolerability

SNRIs

Venlafaxine, Duloxetine

For those not responding to SSRIs

Atypical Antidepressants

Bupropion, Mirtazapine

Less sexual dysfunction (Bupropion); helps insomnia (Mirtazapine)

Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs)

Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline

For treatment-resistant cases

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)

Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine

Reserved for severe, resistant depression

Adjunct Therapy

Atypical antipsychotics, Lithium

For treatment-resistant depression

Treatment Duration:

  • Acute Phase: Minimum of 6 months or length of previous episode (whichever is longer)
  • Maintenance/Prophylaxis: Indicated for 3+ episodes or chronic depression (>2 years)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption is admitted to the hospital with features of confusion, vision loss and an unsteady gait. He is unable to remember the most recent incidents. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Thiamine

Feature

Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Korsakoff Syndrome

Onset

Acute

Chronic often follows Wernicke's

Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

questions.text: Which antidepressant would you recommend for a 38-year-old professor experiencing depression who is concerned about potential sexual dysfunction as a side effect?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Bu

Antidepressant Classes and Their Side Effects

Class

Examples

Mechanism of Action

Common Side Effects

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs)

Fluoxetine, Escitalopram, Sertraline

Inhibit serotonin reuptake, increasing its availability
  • Nausea
  • Insomnia
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Weight gain
  • Emotional blunting

Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (SNRIs)

Venlafaxine, Duloxetine

Inhibit reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine
  • Hypertension (dose-dependent)
  • Nausea
  • Insomnia
  • Sexual dysfunction

Atypical Antidepressants

Bupropion, Mirtazapine

Varies by drug: e.g., Bupropion (NDRI) increases norepinephrine and dopamine
  • Bupropion: Dry mouth, insomnia, low risk of sexual dysfunction
  • Mirtazapine: Sedation, weight gain

Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs)

Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline

Inhibit serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake; block muscarinic, histaminic, and alpha receptors
  • Sedation
  • Weight gain
  • Dry mouth
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Cardiotoxicity (in overdose)

Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs)

Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine

Inhibit monoamine oxidase enzyme, preventing the breakdown of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.
  • Hypertensive crisis (with tyramine-containing foods)
  • Insomnia
  • Hypotension

Serotonin Modulators

Trazodone, Vilazodone

Modulate serotonin receptors and/or reuptake.
  • Trazodone: Sedation, priapism
  • Vilazodone: GI upset, less sexual dysfunction than SSRIs

Noradrenaline and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressants (NaSSAs)

Mirtazapine

Enhances norepinephrine and serotonin transmission by antagonising alpha-2 receptors.
  • Sedation (dose-dependent)
  • Weight gain
  • Low risk of sexual dysfunction

questions.text: What is the predominant manifestation experienced with cannabis consumption?
questions.explanation:
Cannabis

Aspect

Description

Composition
  • Over 400 compounds
  • Includes cannabinoids, flavonoids, and terpenoids
  • Primary psychoactive component: Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)

Forms
  • Dried plant material (marijuana)
  • Bhang (Derived from dried leaves)
  • Ganja (derived from flowering stem)
  • Hashish (concentrated resin)
  • Oils and extracts (Hash oil)
  • Edibles
  • Topical preparations

  • Smoking (most common)
  • Vaporizing
  • Oral ingestion

Clinical Features of Intoxication
  • Tachycardia
  • Conjunctival injection

  • Slowness of time
  • Impaired cognition and motor coordination

  • Increased appetite
  • Nystagmus
  • Postural hypotension
  • Delirium (especially at high doses)

Onset and Duration of Effects
  • Smoking: Rapid onset (minutes), duration 2-3 hours
  • Oral ingestion: Delayed onset (30-90 minutes), duration 4-12 hours

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged man who visits the psychiatry OPD claiming that he has been hearing voices from aliens instructing him to harm his family members for the last seven months?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Schizophrenia

Type of Schizophrenia

Characteristics

Paranoid Schizophrenia

  • Characterised by delusions and hallucinations.
  • Individuals may have a fixed belief that others are out to harm them, often leading to mistrust and vigilance.
  • Cognitive functions usually remain intact, while emotional responses may be inappropriate.

Catatonic Schizophrenia

 

Characterised by three or more of the following symptoms:

  • Motor immobility ( stupor)
  • Excessive, odd movement (stereotypies or mannerisms)
  • Waxy flexibility (bending like a wax candle)
  • Extreme negativism (resisting instructions or maintaining rigidity)
  • Unusual postures (bizarre posturing, catalepsy)
  • Echolalia or echopraxia (Mimicking speech or movements)

Disorganised (Hebephrenic) Schizophrenia
  • Involves disorganised speech and behavior.
  • Inappropriate emotional responses and poor functioning.
  • Typically associated with a poorer prognosis.

Residual Schizophrenia
  • History of schizophrenia with delusions and hallucinations (in the past 1 year) with lingering negative symptoms but minimal or no positive symptoms at present.
  • No prominent delusions or hallucinations
  • Individuals may exhibit social withdrawal and reduced emotional expression.

Simple Schizophrenia

Involves prominent negative symptoms

Undifferentiated Schizophrenia

Diagnosis for patients who do not fit into other categories presenting a mix of symptoms.

questions.text: The first heart sound coincides with which phase of cardiac cycle?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Sub-Phase

Key Events

Systole

Isovolumetric Contraction (Option C)
  • Ventricles begin to contract
  • Ranges from closure of AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) till opening of semilunar valves.
  • First heart sound appears.
  • No blood volume change in ventricles

 

Ventricular Ejection
  • Has 2 phases- Rapid ejection phase and Reduced ejection phase.
  • Ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary pressure
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves open
  • Blood ejected into aorta and pulmonary artery (Option B ruled out)
  • Ventricular volume decreases
  • Ends with the closure of the aortic valve.

Diastole

Isovolumetric Relaxation (Option D ruled out)
  • Ventricles relax
  • Ventricular pressure drops
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves close
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
  • Second heart sounds appears.
  • Ends with the opening of AV valves.

 

Rapid Filling
  • AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) open
  • Blood flows rapidly from atria to ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases rapidly
  • Third heart sound appears.

 

Diastasis
  • Blood flow from atria to ventricles slows
  • No change in the atrial and ventricular pressure.
  • Ventricular volume increases slowly

 

Atrial Systole
  • Atria contract
  • Additional blood pushed into ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases slightly
  • End-diastolic volume (EDV) reached
  • Fourth heart sound is produced.

questions.text: Which change is least likely to occur among a group of colleagues taking an excursion to a high-altitude mountain region?
questions.explanation:
Changes during Acclimatization in high altitudes

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation. (Option D ruled out)
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis.
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Haematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count. (Option B ruled out)
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular
  • Hypoxia activates the sympathoadrenal axis, increasing heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content. (Option C ruled out)
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

The presence of a prominent 'v' wave of jugular venous pulse is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Wave

Details

Abnormalities

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

Prominent a Wave: Tricuspid stenosis (Option C ruled out), right ventricular hypertrophy, pulmonary hypertension.

Absent a Wave: Atrial fibrillation (Option D ruled out)

Cannon a Wave: Atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve

 

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

-

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

Steep x Descent: Constrictive pericarditis, cardiac tamponade.

 

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

Prominent v Wave: Tricuspid regurgitation (Option A)

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

Steep y Descent: Rapid ventricular filling due to high atrial pressure.

 

Absent y Descent: Obstruction to ventricular filling (severe hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal constituent of serum osmolality?
Which of the following statements is accurate regarding creatinine clearance?
questions.explanation:
Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: Which among the following culture media is used in the identification of Salmonella?
A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm as shown below. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods as shown below. Identify the organism.
questions.explanation:
Name

Microscopy

Features

a. Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large (3-10 µm x 1-1.6 µm), rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

It is

 

Characteristic

Description

Blood Agar
  • Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins- giving a frosted glass appearance.
  • Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar.
  • "Medusa head" appearance under microscope.

Agar with Penicillin
  • Susceptible to penicillin.
  • Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml.
  • Forms "string of pearls" chains.

Gelatin Liquefaction

 

 

 

 
  • Obligate aerobe.
  • More growth and energy production at the surface.
  • Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree".

PLET Medium

 

 
  • Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET)
  • Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli.

Serology

 

 

 
  • Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts.
  • DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens.

Laboratory Safety Note
  • High risk of infection from spores.
  • Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

questions.text: In the context of a national public health initiative aimed at addressing anemia, which of the following programs follows the "6x6x6 strategy"?
Plasma sterilization is done by
questions.explanation:
Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat-sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prostheses, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk):

Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.

High-level disinfection (HLD):

Such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

 

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.

Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):

Such as phenols, chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol, povidone-iodine, etc

 

Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes.

 

Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.

questions.text: Which of the following dimorphic fungi causes subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

 

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.
  • Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

 

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows the highest concentration in serum?
The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is?
questions.explanation:
Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis.

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

    • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

    • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

    • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

    • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
    • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
    • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
    • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
    • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

 

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done, and it showed predominantly lymphocytes, sugar- 50mg, and protein- 3000mg/dl. Cobweb coagulum was noted. Gram-staining was negative. The patient's chest X-ray shows upper lobe involvement with hilar lymph node enlargement.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Tuberculous meningitis

Tuberculous Meningitis

Symptoms and Clinical Features:

  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.

  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.

  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.

  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.

  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.

  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.

  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:

  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).

  • High protein content (1–8 g/L).

  • Cobweb Coagulum: Clear fluid in a test tube with a cobweb at the bottom

  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:

  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4–8 weeks, positive in ~50%).

  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10–40%).

  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:

 

  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions -tuberculoma

Treatment:

  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.

  • Initial drug regimen: isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine.

  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.

  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).

  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.
