questions.text: When should a primigravida initiate breastfeeding after a normal delivery of a healthy baby?

A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Subarachnoid haemorrhage

Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Etiology, Risk factors and Pathophysiology

  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space.

  • Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma.

  • Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

  • Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life).

  • Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI).

Epidemiology

  • Age: Most aSAH occurs between ages 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females.

  • Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk.

Etiology

  • Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH):

    • Risk Factors: Hypertension, smoking, family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs, and estrogen deficiency.

    • Rupture Risk: (Option D)

      • Age >60

      • Posterior circulation aneurysms

      • Atherosclerosis

      • Aneurysm size

        • Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk.

        • Aneurysms ≥10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk.

        • Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year.

      • Family history

      • Previous SAH

      • ADPKD

  • Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH):

    • Perimesencephalic NASAH: Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course.

    • Occult Aneurysm: Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging.

    • Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions.

    • Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods.

    • Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders.

Pathophysiology

  • Hemodynamic Stress: Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations.

  • Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow.

    • Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture.

    • Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

Clinical Presentation

 

  • "Thunderclap headache" - worst headache of life

  • Sudden onset severe headache

  • Vomiting

  • Variable LOC

  • Meningismus

  • Retinal hemorrhages

  • Focal neurologic deficits

  • Nuchal rigidity

Diagnosis

CT Head

  • Non-contrast CT is first-line

  • "Star sign" - blood in basal cisterns

  • Sensitivity: 98-100% in first 12 hours

Lumbar Puncture

  • If CT negative

  • Xanthochromia (takes 12h to develop)

  • Elevated opening pressure

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Guillain-Barré syndrome

Category

Symptoms

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
    • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
    • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
    • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
    • Difficulty in climbing stairs
    • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D- Liposomal amphotericin B

Common Cause
  • The leading infectious cause of meningitis in AIDS patients is primarily due to Cryptococcus neoformans (C. neoformans); C. gattii accounts for up to 12%.

Clinical Presentation

 
  • Symptoms include fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs.
  • Low incidence of seizures and focal neurological deficits.
  • Kernig’s Sign- Positive when passive extension of the knee elicits pain; indicative of meningeal irritation.

CSF Profile
  • It may be normal or show modest elevations in WBC and protein levels.
  • Decreased glucose levels may be observed.
  • Elevated CSF opening pressure is typical.

Diagnosis
  • Identification of organisms via India ink examination of CSF.

 

  • Detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF or blood.
  • Blood cultures for fungi are often positive.
  • The biopsy may be necessary for diagnosing CNS cryptococcoma and to differentiate it from immune reconstitution syndrome.

Induction therapy
  • IV amphotericin B (0.7 mg/kg daily) or liposomal amphotericin (4–6 mg/kg daily) plus flucytosine (25 mg/kg qid) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Monitor renal function to avoid flucytosine toxicity.

Maintenance Therapy
  • Amphotericin should be continued until CSF culture is negative, followed by fluconazole (400 mg/d PO for 8 weeks, then 200 mg/d) until CD4+ T-cell count >200 cells/μL for 6 months.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with coarse facial features and gradual enlargement of the hands and feet for the past decade. He has been diagnosed with acromegaly based on elevated levels of IGF-1 and growth hormone that did not suppress after a 75 g glucose challenge test. What drug is recommended for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Lanreotide depot formulation

Management of Acromegaly

Surgical Treatment

Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas.

Post-Surgery:

  • Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery
  • IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days.
  • There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism.

Medical therapy

Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection

  • Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs):
    • Long-acting injectable forms (octreotide, lanreotide).
    • Normalizes GH and IGF-1 levels in about 50% of patients.
    • Side Effects: GI disturbances, transient nausea, and gallbladder issues.
  • GH receptor antagonist:
    • Pegvisomant blocks peripheral GH receptors, normalizing IGF-1 levels in about 70% of patients, though GH levels remain elevated. It is administered through daily subcutaneous injections and is used for recurrences or poor responses to SRLs.
  • Dopamine Agonists:
    • High doses of cabergoline can provide modest GH suppression.

Radiation Therapy

External beam radiation therapy or stereotactic techniques are considered for patients not achieving biochemical control through surgery or medical therapy.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C- Hereditary spherocytosis

Management of Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)

Splenectomy as Primary Treatment
  • Splenectomy significantly improves anemia by prolonging red cell survival, reducing the need for transfusions, and preventing iron overload and related organ damage.
  • Post splenectomy: Spherocytosis and altered osmotic fragility persist, but reticulocyte counts and erythrocyte lifespan normalize.

Blood Film Changes Post-Splenectomy
  • Features like Howell-Jolly bodies, acanthocytes, target cells, cabot ring and Pappenheimer bodies appear after splenectomy.

 

Indications for Splenectomy
  • Recommended for patients with severe, transfusion-dependent anemia, growth failure, skeletal changes, leg ulcers, or extramedullary hematopoietic tumors.

Timing of Splenectomy:

  • Should be delayed until age 5–9 if possible or at least age 3, to reduce the risk of post-splenectomy sepsis while balancing the increased risk of gallstones in older children.

Laparoscopic Splenectomy
  • Preferred method, with benefits like less discomfort, quicker recovery, and shorter hospital stays. Combined laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy is an option for patients with symptomatic gallstones.

Partial Splenectomy
  • Used in infants or young children to alleviate anemia while preserving some splenic immune function. It reduces transfusion needs but may eventually require total splenectomy in about half of patients.

Pre- and Post-Splenectomy Care

 

  • Vaccination: Patients should receive vaccines against pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and meningococcus before surgery.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Use of prophylactic antibiotics post-splenectomy is controversial but recommended by some for at least 5 years or even lifelong.
  • Folic Acid: Continued supplementation (1 mg/day) is recommended to prevent folate deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urine metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Pheochromocytoma

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • Dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor.

 

  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a smoking history presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126mEq/L, AST:62, ALT:56, RBS:112 mg/dl, serum bilirubin of 0.8mg%, and a positive HIV test. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Legionella

Legionnaires' Disease

General Features
  • Incubation period: 2-10 days
  • Non-specific flu-like symptoms initially
  • Often more severe than typical pneumonia

Clinical Features

 

Respiratory

  • Dry cough
  • Shortness of breath
  • Chest pain

Systemic

  • High fever (102-105°F)
  • Headache
  • Myalgias
  • Fatigue

Gastrointestinal

  • Diarrhea
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Abdominal pain

Diagnosis

Laboratory Tests
  • Blood Analysis- Hyponatremia, Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Urinary Antigen- Most common test, rapid results, detects L. pneumophila serogroup-1
  • Culture- Gold standard, requires special media, takes 3-5 days
  • PCR

Imaging Findings

 
  • Chest X-ray: Focal infiltrates/consolidation, predominantly lower lobes
  • CT: Ground-glass opacities, consolidation, pleural effusions possible
  • Can be multilobar in immunocompromised patients

Treatment

 

Mild-Moderate Disease:

  • Azithromycin 500mg PO daily
  • Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily
  • Clarithromycin 500mg PO BID

Severe Disease:

  • Levofloxacin 750mg IV daily
  • Azithromycin 500mg IV daily
  • Consider combination therapy for severe cases

Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Atypical Pneumonia

Outpatients

Hospitalized Patients

Includes M.pneumoniae C.pneumoniae, and Legionella species.

 

Common causes:

  • S.pneumoniae, M.pneumoniae
  • H. influenzae, C.pneumoniae, Respiratory viruses(influenza, RSV).

Non-ICU

ICU Patients

Similar pathogens to outpatients, plus Legionella species.

Pathogens include

S.pneumoniae, S. aureus (including MRSA), Legionella species, gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae.

A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. Chest X-ray shows a 3cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- CT-guided biopsy

Evaluation for Suspected Lung Mass

Non-Invasive Diagnostic Methods

Sputum Cytology
  • Non-invasive initial diagnostic test
  • Most useful for central lesions (Option C Ruled Out)
  • Higher yield in large, proximal tumors
  • Low sensitivity due to high tissue variability

CT Chest
  • Contrast-enhanced
  • Extension to upper abdomen (adrenal level)
  • Sensitivity: 55%, Specificity: 81%
  • Identifies tumor location, extent, and lymph node involvement
  • Lymph node ≥1cm in short axis considered suspicious

PET/PET-CT
  • Higher accuracy than CT (Sensitivity: 80%, Specificity: 88%)
  • Identifies metabolic activity and potential metastases
  • Reduces futile thoracotomies
  • Helpful in identifying recurrence post-therapy

Invasive Staging & Biopsy Methods

CT-Guided Transthoracic Biopsy
  • Preferred for peripheral lesions (Option A)
  • High diagnostic accuracy
  • Minimally Invasive
  • Risk of pneumothorax (especially in emphysematous patients)
  • Contraindicated if high bleeding risk or severe emphysema

EBUS-TBNA
  • CP-EBUS: Real-time sampling of mediastinal/hilar nodes
  • RP-EBUS: For smaller/peripheral lesions
  • Navigation bronchoscopy for mapped approach

Endoscopic-TBNA
  • Samples through esophageal wall
  • Accesses stations 2, 4, 7, 8, 9
  • Sensitivity: 89%, Specificity: 100%

Mediastinoscopy
  • Used after negative needle technique
  • Samples para-tracheal nodes
  • Sensitivity: 78%, Specificity: 100%
  • Mortality risk: 0.08%

VATS/RATS
  • For mediastinal lymph node sampling
  • Full dissection during lung resection
  • Minimally invasive approach

Cancer Type

Location

Primary Investigations

Additional Investigations

Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) - Adenocarcinoma

Peripheral/Outer regions of lung
  • CT-guided needle biopsy
  • PET-CT scan
  • Blood tests for tumor markers (CEA)
  • Molecular testing (EGFR, ALK, ROS1)
  • MRI brain (for staging)
  • Pulmonary function tests

NSCLC - Squamous Cell

Central/Main bronchi
  • Bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • Chest CT with contrast
  • Sputum cytology
  • Mediastinoscopy
  • Bone scan (if symptoms)
  • PD-L1 testing

Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC)

Central regions, rapid spread
  • CT chest/abdomen/pelvis
  • Bronchoscopy
  • Blood tests (ProGRP, NSE)
  • MRI brain (mandatory)
  • Bone marrow biopsy
  • Nuclear medicine scans

Large Cell Carcinoma

Any location
  • PET-CT scan
  • Core needle biopsy
  • Immunohistochemistry
  • Molecular profiling
  • EBUS-TBNA
  • Liquid biopsy

Carcinoid Tumors

Usually central airways
  • Octreotide scan
  • Bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • 24-hour urine 5-HIAA
  • Chromogranin A levels
  • MIBG scan
  • Endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom should be

A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improves as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the probable cause of her headaches?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D- Pseudotumor cerebri

Pseudotumor Cerebri / Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

A disorder associated with elevated CSF pressure without obvious cause, commonly affecting young, obese females

Key Symptoms
  • Headache (worse on waking and with recumbency)
  • Visual disturbances (may be transient)
  • Can occur without visual problems
  • Worse in morning or after lying down
  • Pulsatile tinnitus may be present

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Elevated CSF pressure (>20-25 cm H2O)
  • Normal MRI/MRV findings
  • Normal neurological examination (except for papilledema)
  • Papilledema may be present (but not required for diagnosis)

Initial Treatment
  • Acetazolamide (250-500 mg)
  • Weight loss (if overweight)
  • Serial lumbar punctures may be needed
  • Regular ophthalmologic monitoring

Secondary Treatment
  • Topiramate
  • Other carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • CSF shunting procedures (if needed)
  • Weight loss management programs

Monitoring
  • Regular visual field testing
  • Ophthalmic examination
  • CSF pressure monitoring
  • Weight monitoring
  • Headache diary

Important Considerations
  • Fundoscopic exam should be performed even without overt ophthalmic involvement
  • Consider diagnosis in chronic migraine cases
  • May require long-term management
  • Early intervention is crucial for preventing vision loss

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic tuberculosis was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

options.label: C
options.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

options.label: D
options.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

questions.correct_answer: C. Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C- Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X

Different Modes of Tuberculosis Diagnosis:

Mode of Diagnosis

Description

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum microscopy

Examination of sputum samples under a microscope to detect the presence of acid-fast bacilli (AFB)

Quick and inexpensive

Low sensitivity, especially in cases of paucibacillary disease

Culture and drug susceptibility testing

Growth of TB bacteria in a laboratory setting to determine drug resistance

Highly sensitive and specific

Slow, can take weeks to obtain results

Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs)

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or other molecular tests to detect TB DNA/RNA in sputum or other clinical specimens

Rapid results, high sensitivity and specificity

Expensive, may require specialized equipment and training

Chest X-ray

Imaging of the chest to detect abnormal changes in the lungs

Non-invasive, can detect active TB and TB sequelae

Lack of specificity, cannot differentiate between TB and other lung diseases

Tuberculin skin test (TST)

Injection of PPD under the skin, followed by measurement of induration at the injection site after 48-72 hours

Low cost, widely available

Limited ability to differentiate between latent and active TB

Interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs)

Blood tests that detect TB-specific immune responses

Higher specificity than TST, not affected by BCG vaccination

Higher cost, can be affected by immunosuppression or other medical conditions

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Gaisböck syndrome?

Correct Answer A- Hypotension

Gaisböck syndrome

Key Clinical Features
  • High hematocrit levels
  • Erythrocytosis (Option B Ruled Out)
  • Normal leukocyte counts (Option C Ruled Out)
  • No splenomegaly
  • Hypertension
  • Facial rubor

Patient Characteristics
  • Predominantly affects males
  • Obese and anxious personality (Option D Ruled Out)
  • Often cigarette smokers

Risk Factors
  • Alcoholism
  • Diuretic therapy
  • Physical & Emotional stress
  • Obesity
  • Smoking

Pathophysiological Mechanisms
  • Psychiatric disorders causing chronic stress
  • Volume contraction (diuresis)
  • Hypertension
  • Nocturnal hypoxemia
  • Increased erythropoietin production

Complications
  • Formation of microthrombi
  • Cerebral infarction
  • Vascular disease

Treatment Approach
  • Management of hypertension
  • Weight reduction
  • Smoking cessation
  • Alcohol reduction/cessation
  • Stress management

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Constrictive pericarditis

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

atigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

Organ System

Pathological Features

Clinical Manifestations

Diagnostic Findings

Respiratory
  • Thick mucus plugging

  • Chronic inflammation
  • Submucosal gland hypertrophy
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Recurrent infections
  • Progressive dyspnea
  • Digital clubbing
  • Obstructive pattern on PFTs

Pancreatic
  • Duct obstruction

  • Fibrosis
  • Fat replacement
  • Malabsorption
  • Steatorrhea

  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
  • Low fecal elastase
  • Elevated fecal fat
  • Low vitamins A, D, E, K

Sweat Glands
  • Abnormal chloride transport
  • Normal gland structure
  • Salty-tasting skin
  • Heat intolerance
  • Salt depletion
  • Elevated sweat chloride
  • >60 mEq/L diagnostic

Hepatobiliary
  • Bile duct plugging

  • Elevated liver enzymes

questions.text: In a 60-year-old male, what is the primary etiology typically associated with Cushing's disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D- Pituitary microadenoma

Cushing's syndrome- Definition and Causes

Definition:
  • Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.
  • Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.
  • It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.

Causes:

Cushing's syndrome can be caused by various factors, categorised as ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

I) ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome accounts for approximately 90% of cases.

  • Cushing's disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) is the most common cause.
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs when a non-pituitary tumour secretes ACTH.

II) ACTH-independent Cushing's Syndrome constitutes the remaining 10% of cases.

  • Adrenocortical adenoma is the most prevalent cause, accounting for 5–10% of all cases.
  • Rare causes include:
    • Primary bilateral macronodular adrenal hyperplasia (PBMAH)
    • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease (PPNAD)
    • McCune-Albright syndrome

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family reported a previous history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor made a tentative diagnosis based on the clinical symptoms. What would be the most appropriate investigative method to establish a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C- Sestamibi scan

Primary Hyperparathyroidism- Lab and Radiological findings

Lab Investigations

Serum calcium levels

Increased

Serum phosphate levels

Decreased

Serum alkaline phosphatase (SAP) levels

Increased

Serum PTH (parathyroid hormone) assay

Elevated PTH

Radiological features

Features

Image

Subperiosteal erosions and terminal resorption in the phalanges (usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side) along with bone demineralisation.

The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull).

 

 

Brown tumour or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions in bone from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can lead to bone expansion, accompanied by bleeding and granulation tissue.

Sestamibi scan (Tc-99): Localize the parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B- Dermatomyositis

Dermatomyositis

Definition

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

Clinical features

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.
  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers, on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles
  • CMVE is seen over other sites too, and is named accordingly.

 

  • Heliotrope rash: CMVE over the periorbital skin
  • V-Sign: CMVE over the anterior aspect of the neck
  • Shawl sign: Involvement of upper back
  • Holster sign: Rash over the lateral aspect of the thigh
  • Mechanic’s hand: Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the edges of the fingers

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A- Myasthenia gravis

Clinical Features and Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis

Clinical Features
  • Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia
  • Weakness in oculomotor, pharyngeal, limb, neck extensors
  • Fluctuation and fatigue worse with activity, improved by rest
  • Fatiguability increases as the day passes (diurnal variation)
  • Initial symptoms frequently ocular (diplopia/ptosis)
  • Facial weakness produces "snarling" expression

Physical Examination
  • Eye movements and ptosis
  • Assessment of muscle strength in neck and extremities
  • Weakness following repetitive muscle activation
  • Normal deep tendon reflexes
  • No sensory abnormalities
  • Symptoms relieved by Anticholinesterases

Diagnostic Tests
  • Anti-AChR antibodies (positive in ~85% generalized MG)
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies (in ~40% of AChR-negative cases)
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Single-fiber EMG
  • CT or MRI of chest (to evaluate thymus)

Clinical Tests
  • Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: 2mg + 8mg IV
  • Ice pack test for ptosis
  • Fatigue testing (repeated muscle activation)

questions.text: Study of death in all aspects is known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Thanatolog

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, it is found that the patient has conductive hearing loss and the Rinne test results are negative. Additionally, a reddish mass is observed located behind the tympanic membrane. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Glomus tumor (Paraganglioma)

Definition

Tumors originating from the paraganglia are known as paragangliomas, with glomus tumors being a specific type of paraganglioma.

Tumour type

Benign (most common benign tumor of middle ear)

Origin

Paraganglionic cells or glomus bodies .

Prevalence

Commonly seen in middle-aged individuals (40-50 years), with a higher prevalence in females

Types

  1. Glomus tympanicum: Arise from the promontory of the middle ear (tympanic plexus).
  2. Glomus jugulare: Arises from the dome of the jugular bulb (sympathetic plexus covering the jugular vein).

Spread

  • Inferiorly: To the jugular foramen
  • Anteriorly: Invading into the nasopharynx (blockage of eustachian tube)
  • Posteriorly: Invading the mastoid
  • Superiorly: To the posterior and middle cranial fossa (IX-XII cranial nerve palsy)
  • Laterally: To the tympanic membrane (present as a bleeding polyp of the external auditory canal).
  • Medially: Invading the labyrinth and petrous pyramid (dizziness and facial palsy).

 

Clinical manifestations
  • Hearing loss (gradually progressive conductive hearing loss)
  • Pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat like sounds): It is synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Bleeding from ear (profuse bleeding in case of polyp)
  • Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear.
  • Symptoms like headache, sweating, palpitation, hypertension, anxiety due to sympathetic excess (catecholamine release)

Histopathology

  • No capsule (locally invasive)
  • HPE reveals Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

Otoscopy

  • Red reflex through intact tympanic membrane and bulging tympanic membrane (glomus tympanicum).
  • “Rising sun" appearance due to the tumor originating from the floor of middle ear (glomus jugulare).

Diagnosis

  • CECT (IOC) shows erosion of the carotico-jugular spine on the diseased side, known as Phelp’s sign.
  • MRI scan revealed microhemorrhages within the tumor which appear as white and gray dots on MRI, creating a "salt and pepper" appearance.
  • Angiography is used to identify the arteries supplying the tumor.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient is presented, as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis
  • It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

Absidia

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

 b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b.Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a neonate presenting with frothing from the mouth and respiratory distress, with the X-ray provided below?
questions.correct_answer: C. Esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula

Tracheoesophageal fistula

Causes
  • Embryology: Disruption during embryonic development of the trachea and oesophagus.
  • Genetic Factors: Associated with syndromes like Feingold syndrome, CHARGE syndrome, and anophthalmia-esophageal-genital syndrome.
  • Unknown Etiology: Factors such as advanced maternal age, ethnicity, obesity, low socioeconomic status, and smoking may be involved.

Types of TEF
  • Type A: Isolated oesophagal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Type B: Esophageal atresia with proximal tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Type C: Proximal oesophagal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Type D: Esophageal atresia with both proximal and distal tracheoesophageal fistulas
  • Type E: Isolated tracheoesophageal fistula without associated oesophagal atresia

Presentation
  • Classic Symptoms: Frothing and bubbling at the mouth and nose, coughing, cyanosis, respiratory distress exacerbated by feeding.
  • Aspiration Pneumonia: More severe with distal fistula.
  • H-Type Fistula: Chronic respiratory issues, bronchospasm, recurrent pneumonia in isolated cases.

Diagnosis
  • Esophagogram
  • Chest X-ray shows a gas-filled or gasless abdomen and a coiled tube in the upper oesophagus.

Management
  • Immediate Care: Maintain airway patency, prevent aspiration, and use antibiotics.
  • Surgical Repair: Standard involves ligation of TEF and primary end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Alternative Approaches: Delayed primary closure, fistula ligation, gastrostomy tube placement, or using gastric, jejunal, or colonic segments if the gap >3-4 cm.

Complications
  • Respiratory Complications: Risk of aspiration pneumonia.
  • Esophageal Complications: Feeding difficulties, failure to thrive.
  • Associated Anomalies: Often part of VACTERL association (vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, limb).

Prognosis
  • Improved Outcomes: Better survival rates due to advancements in care.
  • Long-Term Complications: Potential issues include feeding difficulties, esophageal strictures, and respiratory problems.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does a patient with Reinke's edema classically present with?

options.label: C

questions.text: What kind of family would the surveyor categorize the household as, considering it consists of a 35-year-old man, his 6-week pregnant wife, a 3-year old child, and the temporary presence of the man's brother and his wife during their winter vacation?
What is the fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose

Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition

Step

Diagnosis

Initial Management

Monitoring

1. Treat/Prevent Hypoglycemia

Blood glucose <54 mg/dL (3 mmol/L)

Asymptomatic:

  • 50 mL of 10% glucose/sucrose orally/NG
  • Follow with first feed
  • F-75 starter diet every 2 hours

Symptomatic:

  • 10% dextrose IV 5 mL/kg
  • Follow with 50 mL 10% glucose via NG tube
  • Start antibiotics immediately
  • Blood glucose every 30 minutes until stable
  • Level of consciousness
  • Vital signs every 2 hours
  • Feed intake volume
  • Signs of deterioration

2. Treat/Prevent Hypothermia

Temperature <35.5°C (rectal) or <35°C (axillary)

Immediate interventions:

  • Warm clothing with head cover
  • Skin-to-skin contact with mother
  • Warm room (25-30°C)
  • Warm feeds
  • Overhead warmer/heat convector

Avoid:

  • Rapid rewarming
  • Direct heat sources
  • Prolonged exposure
  • Temperature every 30 minutes until >36.5°C
  • Then every 2 hours until >37.5°C
  • Watch for overheating
  • Monitor blood glucose
  • Check for infection signs

3. Treat/Prevent Dehydration

Clinical signs:

  • Thirst
  • Sunken eyes
  • Reduced skin turgor
  • Weak pulses
  • Cold extremities

ReSoMal administration:

  • 5-10 mL/kg/hour for first 12 hours
  • Maximum 12 hours for rehydration
  • Replace ongoing losses

If shock present:

  • Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose
  • 15 mL/kg over first hour
  • Reassess and repeat if needed

Every 30 minutes for first 2 hours:

  • Pulse rate
  • Respiratory rate
  • Urine output
  • Stool frequency
  • Signs of overhydration
  • Mental status

4. Correct Electrolyte Imbalance

Common abnormalities:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Excess total body sodium
  • Metabolic acidosis

Potassium supplementation:

  • 3-4 mEq/kg/day
  • Continue for 2 weeks

Magnesium:

  • Day 1: 0.3 mL/kg IM (max 2 mL)
  • Then 0.8-1.2 mEq/kg/day oral

Restrict sodium intake
  • Daily electrolytes
  • ECG if severe hypokalemia
  • Clinical signs of deficiency
  • Urine output
  • Mental status changes

5. Treat/Prevent Infection

Screen for:

  • Sepsis
  • Pneumonia
  • UTI
  • TB
  • HIV
  • Malaria in endemic areas

First-line antibiotics:

  • Ampicillin 50 mg/kg 6 hourly
  • Gentamicin 7.5 mg/kg daily

If no improvement in 48h:

  • Cefotaxime 100-150 mg/kg/day
  • or Ceftriaxone 50-75 mg/kg/day
  • Temperature
  • Respiratory rate
  • Heart rate
  • Clinical response
  • Culture results
  • Inflammatory markers

6. Micronutrient Supplementation

Common deficiencies:

  • Vitamin A
  • Zinc
  • Iron
  • Folic acid
  • Copper
  • Other vitamins/minerals

Vitamin A (Day 1):

  • 6-12 months: 100,000 IU
  • >12 months: 200,000 IU

Daily supplements:

  • Folic acid 1mg/day
  • Zinc 2mg/kg/day
  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day
  • Iron 3mg/kg/day (after stabilization)
  • Clinical signs of deficiency
  • Response to therapy
  • Weight gain
  • Appetite improvement
  • Complications

7. Initiate Feeding

Assessment:

  • Appetite
  • Ability to feed
  • Complications
  • Metabolic status

Initial feeding:

  • F-75 formula (75 kcal/100 mL)
  • Start 80 kcal/kg/day
  • Increase to 100 kcal/kg/day
  • 2-hourly feeds initially

Volume per feed:

11 mL/kg/feed initially
  • Feed tolerance
  • Volume consumed
  • Weight changes
  • Edema
  • Vomiting/diarrhea
  • Refeeding syndrome

8. Catch-up Growth

Indicators for transition:

  • Return of appetite
  • Reduced/resolved edema
  • Metabolic stability
  • Infection control

Transition to F-100:

  • Increase to 150-200 kcal/kg/day
  • Protein 4-6 g/kg/day
  • 6 feeds per day
  • Gradual volume increase

Target weight gain: >10 g/kg/day
  • Daily weight
  • Height weekly
  • MUAC weekly
  • Appetite
  • Clinical status
  • Feed intake

9. Sensory Stimulation

Assess:

  • Developmental status
  • Interaction level
  • Physical capabilities
  • Emotional state

Daily activities:

  • Structured play 15-30 min
  • Physical activity as tolerated
  • Emotional support
  • Mother-child bonding
  • Age-appropriate stimulation
  • Development progress
  • Activity level
  • Social interaction
  • Emotional response
  • Motor skills

10. Prepare for Follow-up

Discharge criteria:

  • No edema x 2 weeks
  • Weight-for-height > -2 SD
  • Good appetite
  • Clinically well
  • Completed immunizations

Discharge planning:

  • Family education
  • Follow-up schedule
  • Community health worker linkage
  • Emergency care plan
  • Nutrition counseling

Post-discharge:

  • Weekly follow-up initially
  • Monthly weight checks
  • Growth monitoring
  • Development assessment
  • Immunization status

Which of the following is not a correct match for ABCD according to pediatric advanced life support?

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 5-year-old girl presented to the clinic with symptoms of fever, cough, red eyes, running nose, and rash, as depicted in the image of the child's appearance?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Measles

Measles

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

 

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.correct_answer: A. Kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ In a diverse population, such as the one in urban Delhi, stratified random sampling is an effective method to ensure that different subgroups (or strata) of the population are represented in the sample.
  • ↳ stratified random sampling
  • ↳ In this case, the population can be divided into subgroups based on factors like socioeconomic status, age, dietary preferences, or geographic location within the urban region.
  • ↳ After dividing the population into strata, random samples are then taken from each group, ensuring that the sample is representative of the entire population.
  • ↳ Cluster random sampling (Option A): is incorrect because cluster sampling is used when the population is divided into clusters, often geographically, and entire clusters are randomly selected. While this can be used in large-scale studies, it doesn't specifically ensure representation of the diverse subgroups within the population as well as stratified sampling.
  • ↳ Cluster random sampling (Option A):
  • ↳ cluster sampling
  • ↳ Simple random sampling (Option C): is incorrect because simple random sampling involves selecting individuals from the entire population randomly without considering any subgroups. While it may still give a sample, it may not adequately represent the diverse dietary habits of the population in urban Delhi.
  • ↳ Simple random sampling (Option C):
  • ↳ simple random sampling
  • ↳ Systematic random sampling (Option D): is incorrect because systematic random sampling involves selecting every nth individual from a list or a sequence of individuals. While it's easier to implement, it doesn't ensure that different groups within the population are represented as effectively as stratified sampling.
  • ↳ Systematic random sampling (Option D):
  • ↳ systematic random sampling

questions.text: Giving class in a village for wound care after a dog bite by enacting it is which mode of health communication?
Gonadal growth corresponds with _____.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Sk

Brain growth

The brain enlarges rapidly during the latter months of fetal life and early months of postnatal life. At birth, the head size is about 65-70% of the expected head size in adults. It reaches 90% of the adult head size in two years. Full adult size is reached by age 6.

Growth of gonads

Gonadal growth is dormant during childhood and becomes conspicuous during puberty.

Growth of body fat and muscle mass

Body tissues can be divided into fat and fat-free (lean) components. The lean body mass includes muscle tissue, internal organs, and skeleton. The growth in lean body mass is primarily due to increased skeletal and muscle mass. Lean body mass correlates closely with stature.

Skeletal growth

Skeletal growth is a continuous process occurring throughout childhood and adolescence. It is steady until the pubertal growth spurt when it accelerates and subsequently slows considerably. The skeleton matures once the epiphysis or growth plates at the end of long bones fuse to the shaft or diaphysis. This occurs by about 18 years in girls and 20-22 years in boys.

Lymphoid growth

The growth of lymphoid tissue is most notable during the mid-childhood. During this period, the lymphoid tissue is overgrown, and its mass may appear larger than that of a fully mature adult. It reaches 200% of adult size during childhood.

questions.text: According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol, below what heart rate are chest compressions initiated?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - 60

NRP Neonatal Chest Compressions Guidelines

Indications
  • Heart rate below 60/min despite 30 seconds of PPV
  • Continue until heart rate is 60/min or more

Technique
  • Two-thumb technique is preferred
  • Thumbs depress lower third of sternum
  • Hands encircle torso with fingers supporting back
  • Avoid using xiphisternum
  • Thumbs remain in contact during compression and release

Depth & Rate
  • Compress chest three times
  • One breath for ventilation
  • Use 3:1 ratio (compression:ventilation)
  • Complete cycle in 2 minutes
  • Check femoral or carotid pulse periodically

Evaluation
  • Check heart rate after 60 seconds of CC
  • HR below 60: Continue CC with PPV and medications
  • HR 60 or above: Stop CC, continue PPV until HR >100 and spontaneous breathing

Important Considerations
  • Must always accompany with BMV (bag-mask ventilation)
  • Only oxygenated blood should be circulated
  • Ventilate between compressions
  • Positive breath should follow every third CC

Complications
  • Broken ribs
  • Liver laceration
  • Pneumothorax

Asbestos exposure may be associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer
  • It is not associated with smoking

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene - CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin
    • Epithelial membrane antigen
    • Cytokeratin
    • Mesothelin

Prognosis

Poor (median survival of 9-21 months).

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of hemolytic anaemia?
What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.explanation:
Parts of the Inner Ear

The inner ear, or labyrinth, is essential for hearing and balance and is located within the temporal bone. It consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth.

Bony Labyrinth

A rigid structure filled with perilymph (a sodium-rich fluid), it has three main parts:

  1. Vestibule: Central part connecting to the cochlea and semicircular canals.
    • Bony Recesses in the vestibule contains the utricle and saccule (part of the membranous labyrinth).
      • Spherical Recess: Contains the saccule, a membranous sac involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration.
      • Elliptical Recess: Contains the utricle, which works with the saccule to aid in balance and spatial orientation.
    • Oval Window: Located on the vestibule’s lateral wall, it connects to the middle ear.
    • Openings of the Semicircular Canals: The three semicircular canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) have five openings into the vestibule, enabling detection of head rotations.
    • Opening of the Vestibular Aqueduct: Positioned below the elliptical recess, it allows the passage of the endolymphatic duct, which carries endolymph within the membranous labyrinth.
  2. Semicircular Canals: Three canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) positioned at right angles to detect rotational head movement. Each has an ampulla containing the crista ampullaris for sensory function.
  3. Cochlea: A spiral structure essential for hearing, divided into three chambers (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media). The scala vestibuli and tympani contain perilymph and communicate via the helicotrema, while the scala media houses the organ of Corti, which converts sound vibrations into electrical signals.

 

Membranous Labyrinth

 

A delicate system within the bony labyrinth, filled with potassium-rich endolymph, it includes:

  1. Cochlear Duct (Scala Media): Inside the cochlea, it separates the scala vestibuli and scala tympani and contains the organ of Corti for hearing.
  2. Utricle and Saccule: Membranous sacs in the vestibule responsible for detecting linear acceleration and balance. They are connected via the utriculosaccular duct.
  3. Semicircular Ducts: Membranous ducts within the bony semicircular canals, contributing to balance.
  4. Endolymphatic Duct and Sac: Extending from the utricle and saccule, the duct ends in the endolymphatic sac, important in surgical treatments for conditions like Ménière's disease.

A 60-year-old patient presents with chronic dacryocystitis. She complains of recurrent tearing, discharge, and mild swelling in the inner corner of the eye. The clinical findings and history are consistent with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Dacryocystorhinostomy

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  4. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

 

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later.
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage.
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age.

Histopathological variants of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma

1. Mononuclear cells
  • Single nucleus with a large, inclusion-like nucleolus with abundant cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma

2. Popcorn cells
  • Cells with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Nodular lymphocyte - Predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

3. Reed-sternberg cell

It is characterised by two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm and is typically surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.

4. Lacunar cells
  • Typically found in the nodular sclerosis subtype.
  • Nuclei are more delicate, folded, or multilobate.
  • Abundant pale cytoplasm often gets disrupted during sectioning, creating an appearance where the nucleus sits in an empty space (lacuna).

questions.text: What is the probable medical condition for a 70-year-old individual who has relied on presbyopia glasses but can now comfortably read the newspaper without them?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Index myopia:

Type of Myopia

Cause

Axial Myopia

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form).

Curvatural Myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Positional Myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye.

Index Myopia

Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis.

Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation

Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power.

Clinical features

  • Asthenopic symptoms
  • Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity
  • Prominent eyeball.
  • Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils.
  • Slightly deeper anterior chamber.
  • Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen.
  
 

Treatment
  • Prescription of appropriate concave lenses
  • Surgical Treatment

questions.text: In a three-year-old boy, his parents have noticed a progressive decline in coordination over the last six months. During a physical examination, a growth resembling a cauliflower is observed in the left eye, along with leukocoria and the absence of a red reflex. Microscopic analysis of the sample reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which gene is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Rb gene

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

questions.text: What kind of laser can be utilized to treat posterior capsular opacification, which is observed during an examination of a patient who has reported decreased visual acuity following cataract surgery?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Nd YAG laser

Definition
  • M/C postoperative complication following extracapsular lens extraction.

Clinical Types
  • Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO): Common form of after cataract.
  • Dense Membranous After Cataract: Thick membrane formation.
  • Soemmering's Ring: Thick ring behind the iris, enclosed between capsule layers.

 

  • Elschnig's Pearls: Clustered, vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells along the posterior capsule.

Treatment
  • ND YAG laser posterior capsulotomy

A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.explanation:
Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks (Option B & C)

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks (Option D)
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

Trimester

Regimen

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Best method with a high success rate.

 

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

Used when Mifepristone is not available.

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

Less commonly used.

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline.

Longer induction duration is rarely used.

Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around - 610 mmHg.

 

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

 
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

Karman’s cannula

 

Hegar’s dilator

 

Uterine curette

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)

  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

Ovum forceps

Hysterotomy

  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

Key Features

Spatially Fractionated Radiation Therapy (SFRT)

Delivers heterogeneous doses to spare normal tissue, effective in bulky tumors.

Hyperfractionation

More frequent, smaller doses to enhance local control.

Accelerated Fractionation

Shortens overall treatment time, maintaining or enhancing efficacy.

questions.text: Please identify the section of the intestine shown in the barium study provided.
questions.explanation:
Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia

"Single bubble" sign

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.

 

Duodenal Atresia

"Double bubble" sign

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

Jejunal Atresia

"Triple bubble" sign

Three distended loops of bowel (stomach, duodenum, proximal jejunum) with no distal gas.

Ileal Atresia

Multiple air-fluid levels

Dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels and no gas in the large intestine, more distal than jejunal atresia.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

Postpartum Blues (Option B)

Postpartum Depression (Option A)

Postpartum Psychosis (Option C)

Onset

4-5 days after delivery, lasts a few days

Gradual onset over 4-6 months following delivery or abortion

Sudden, typically within 4-6 weeks after delivery

Duration

Transient, lasts for a few days

Can persist beyond postpartum period

Can persist beyond postpartum period

Symptoms
  • Depression
  • Anxiety
  • Tearfulness
  • Insomnia
  • Negative feelings
  • Mood swings
  • Loss of energy and appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal attitude
  • Fear
  • Restlessness
  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions
  • Disorientation
  • Suicidal and infantile impulses

Treatment
  • Reassurance
  • psychological support
  • CBT
  • SSRIs, estrogen Patch later.
  • Urgent psychiatric consultation, hospitalization.
  • Chlorpromazine, sublingual estradiol, lithium, ECT (if necessary)

Prognosis

Good

Good with treatment

High risk of recurrence

Breastfeeding

Generally safe

Safe with SSRIs

Contraindicated with some medications (Lithium)

A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with chills and rigors. She has acute pain in the right flank region. The imaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Acute Pyelonephritis

Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis

Ultrasound (USG): This may show kidney enlargement, reduced echogenicity, and dilated collecting systems.

 

 

 

Ultrasound (USG): Shows an enlarged kidney with echogenic staghorn calculi and hypoechoic masses replacing renal parenchyma.

 

 

Plain Abdominal X-ray: Detects gas in the kidney region in about 70% of cases.

 

 

Contrast-enhanced CT: Most sensitive, showing wedge-shaped hypodense areas, striated nephrograms, and pelvic wall thickening.

 

CT Scan reveals a non-functioning kidney, staghorn calculus, expanded calyces, and inflammatory changes. A characteristic bear paw sign is noted.

 

CT: Gold standard, reveals gas within the kidney, renal enlargement, perinephric stranding and abscesses. Helps classify into Type 1 (gas without fluid) or Type 2 (gas with fluid).

 

Acute infection of the kidney involving the renal parenchyma and collecting system is usually caused by ascending bacteria.
  • It is a chronic granulomatous response to recurrent renal infection - that leads to the destruction of renal parenchyma and its replacement by lipid-laden foamy macrophages.
  • Destruction spreads from the renal pelvis→medulla→ cortex.
  • Usually, staghorn calculus is present in the pelvis.

Severe necrotizing infection with gas accumulation in and around the kidney, primarily in diabetic patients.

A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Dermatomyositis

Dermatomyositis

Definition

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

 

Clinical features

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.

  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers, on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles
  • CMVE is seen over other sites too, and is named accordingly.
    • Heliotrope rash: CMVE over the periorbital skin

    • V-Sign: CMVE over the anterior aspect of the neck

    • Shawl sign: Involvement of upper back

    • Holster sign: Rash over the lateral aspect of the thigh

    • Mechanic’s hand: Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the edges of the fingers

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Myasthenia gravis

Clinical Features and Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis

Clinical Features
  • Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia
  • Weakness in oculomotor, pharyngeal, limb, neck extensors
  • Fluctuation and fatigue worse with activity, improved by rest
  • Fatiguability increases as the day passes (diurnal variation)
  • Initial symptoms frequently ocular (diplopia/ptosis)
  • Facial weakness produces "snarling" expression

Physical Examination
  • Eye movements and ptosis
  • Assessment of muscle strength in neck and extremities
  • Weakness following repetitive muscle activation
  • Normal deep tendon reflexes
  • No sensory abnormalities
  • Symptoms relieved by Anticholinesterases

Diagnostic Tests
  • Anti-AChR antibodies (positive in ~85% generalized MG)
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies (in ~40% of AChR-negative cases)
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Single-fiber EMG
  • CT or MRI of chest (to evaluate thymus)

Clinical Tests
  • Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: 2mg + 8mg IV
  • Ice pack test for ptosis
  • Fatigue testing (repeated muscle activation)

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves:

options.label: A
options.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

options.label: B
options.text: Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face

options.label: C
options.text: Ipsilateral lower half of the face

options.label: D
options.text: Contralateral lower half of the face

questions.correct_answer: A. Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

Bell’s Palsy

Causes
  • Inflammation of facial nerve
  • HSV-1 reactivation- Common cause
  • VZV reactivation in Ramsay Hunt
  • Edema within facial canal

Clinical Features
  • Acute onset (24-72 hours)
  • Complete unilateral facial paralysis
  • Loss of taste anterior 2/3 tongue
  • Hyperacusis (stapedius paralysis)
  • Decreased tear production
  • Bell's phenomenon present

Diagnostic Approach
  • Clinical diagnosis primary
  • EMG/NCS if no improvement
  • MRI if atypical features
  • CSF analysis if indicated
  • Lyme titers in endemic areas

Treatment & Prognosis
  • Prednisone 60-80mg × 5 days
  • Valacyclovir 1000mg TID × 5-7 days
  • Eye protection crucial
  • 80% recovery rate
  • Axonal degeneration = worse prognosis
  • Incomplete paralysis in 1st week = best prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Metoprolol

First-line drugs used in the treatment of Chronic CHF (mortality-reducing)

ARBs/ACE-inhibitors/ARNI
  • Either of these can be started as initial therapy.
  • ACE-inhibitors: Captopril, Enalapril
  • ARBs: Telmisartan, Olmesartan
  • ARNI: ARB+Neprilysin inhibitor - Valsartan-Sacubitril (most preferred 1st line drug)
  • ADR: Cough, angioedema

Beta-blockers
  • Cardioselective (2nd gen): Metoprolol, Bisoprolol
  • 3rd gen: Carvedilol (both α- & β- blocking action) - Best beta blocker for heart failure
  • ADR: Bradycardia, Hypotension

SGLT-2 Inhibitors
  • Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin
  • ADR: UTI, Forunier gangrene, Euglycemic DKA

Aldosterone antagonists
  • Spironolactone
  • ADR: Gynaecomastia
